title:
Mutual Coupling-Aware Channel Estimation and Beamforming for
  RIS-Assisted Communications

sections.text:
#### Abstract

This work studies the problems of channel estimation and beamforming for active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communication, incorporating the mutual coupling (MC) effect through an electromagnetically consistent model based on scattering parameters. We first demonstrate that MC can be incorporated into a compressed sensing (CS) estimation formulation, albeit with an increase in the dimensionality of the sensing matrix. To overcome this increased complexity, we propose a two-stage strategy. Initially, a low-complexity MC-unaware CS estimation is performed to obtain a coarse channel estimate, which is then used to implement a dictionary reduction (DR), effectively reducing the dimensionality of the sensing matrices. This method achieves low complexity comparable to the conventional MC-unaware approach while providing estimation accuracy close to that of the high-complexity MC-aware CS method. Furthermore, we consider the joint optimization of RIS configuration, base station precoding, and user combining in an single-user MIMO system. We employ an alternating optimization strategy to optimize these three beamformers. The primary challenge lies in optimizing the RIS configuration, as the MC effect renders the problem non-convex and intractable. To address this, we propose a novel algorithm based on the successive convex approximation (SCA) and the Neumann series expansion. Within the SCA framework, we propose a surrogate function that rigorously satisfies both convexity and equal-gradient conditions to update the iteration direction. Numerical results validate our proposal, demonstrating that the proposed channel estimation and beamforming methods effectively manage the MC in RIS, achieving higher spectral efficiency compared to state-of-the-art approaches.


Index Terms-Mutual coupling, scattering parameter, active reconfigurable intelligent surface, compressed sensing, dictionary reduction, successive convex approximation, Neumann series.

## I. INTRODUCTION

Next-generation wireless networks are expected to extend spectral and energy efficiency, peak data rates, and network capacity, necessitating the integration of emerging technologies and game-changing enablers. For example, the quest

for abundant contiguous bandwidth drives these networks to shift from conventional sub-6 gigahertz ( GHz ) frequencies to higher bands, including upper mid-band [1], millimeterwave (mmWave) [2], sub-terahertz (THz) [3], and THz [4]. However, higher frequencies present challenges such as increased free space path loss and a higher likelihood of blockage, which limit communication distances and reduce link availability. To mitigate these effects, the integration of reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS), also known as intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) [5], [6], offers a viable solution. RIS technology facilitates real-time, intelligent manipulation of electromagnetic (EM) waves to enhance wireless communication performance [5], [7], while also enabling novel applications [8]-[11].

An RIS is a planar metamaterial-based surface composed of a large number of nearly passive reflecting elements. Various types of RIS have been invented to extend their capability in different scenarios. For example, utilizing reflection-type amplifiers [12], active RIS have been proposed to overcome the limited capacity gains of passive RISs and alleviate the multiplicative fading effect [13]. Additionally, extremely dense and even holographic RISs have gained attention recently for their utmost flexibility and precision in recording and shaping arbitrary-intended EM waves with high energy efficiency [14][16]. Although promising, these novel RIS hardware designs introduce new challenges in wireless communications. One of the most pronounced issues is the mutual coupling (MC) effect. Initial investigations indicate that densifying the RIS layout will significantly strengthen the mutual coupling among adjacent RIS unit cells [17], [18]. Furthermore, increasing the RIS amplification coefficients can also substantially exacerbate the impact of MC on channel estimation and localization [19]. Therefore, accurate modeling and sophisticated signal processing for such EM interactions among adjacent RIS unit cells are essential for optimizing performance and maximizing the benefits of such surfaces.

## A. Related Work

1) Conventional RIS Modeling: The most commonly adopted model for RIS-assisted communication describes the RIS reflection as a linear cascaded channel. That is, the overall channel between transmitter (Tx) and receiver (Rx) is the multiplication of the Tx-RIS subchannel, the RIS reflection response, and the RIS-Rx subchannel [7], [10], [19]. While offering significant mathematical tractability, such linear modeling tacitly assumes that each RIS unit cell radiates

EM waves independently, neglecting the nonlinear coupling between these unit cells. Recently, the results in [20] cast doubt on this common linear cascaded model, suggesting it poorly describes the physical reality. As analyzed in [20], the mutual coupling can result from the proximity-induced coupling due to adjacent radiators, and the reverberation-induced long-range coupling due to environmental scattering multipath. Both mechanisms are characterized by nonlinear interactions. The neglect of proximity-induced coupling becomes untenable when considering densely integrated RIS. Meanwhile, overlooking reverberation-induced long-range coupling presents challenges in rich-scattering environments.
2) MC-Aware RIS Modeling: Notable efforts have been dedicated to accurately accounting for mutual coupling in RIS-assisted communications. For instance, based on the firstprinciples coupled-dipole formalism, a physics-based end-toend model called PhysFad [21] has been proposed. This model provides a tuning mechanism for jointly modeling transceivers, RIS elements, and the scattering environment. Another suitable theory for modeling mutual coupling is the microwave multiport network theory [22], [23], which extends basic circuit and network concepts to handle complex microwave analyses. Typically, three equivalent representations can be used to analyze microwave networks: impedance, admittance, and scattering parameters [24]. An impedance matrix (Z-parameters) model of MC was first adopted in [17]. Subsequently, equivalent models based on the scattering matrix (S-parameters) have been developed [25]. These models are essentially equivalent and have been unified in, e.g., [24], [26], [27]. From a practical perspective, the scattering matrix model has the advantage of being more directly related to the radiation pattern [28] and verifiable by measurements, as demonstrated in our previous MC measurement work [29].
3) Channel Estimation: Considering the sparse channel nature in the mmWave [2] and THz [3], [4] bands, earlier investigations in [30], based on the conventional cascaded model, demonstrated that channel estimation can be formulated as a sparse signal recovery problem, which can be solved using compressed sensing (CS) techniques. In [31] and [32], CS-based channel estimation in multi-user scenarios was formulated and addressed based on the conventional linear model by leveraging double-structured sparsity. Other works such as [33], [34] proposed two-stage channel estimation methods that decouple the cascaded channel into two separate subproblems. However, none of these previous studies account for MC. Moreover, prior information can be incorporated with CS tools to significantly boost the performance on many levels, such as weighted CS algorithms, structured codebook design, and dictionary design as shown in [35]-[37], which has not been investigated for RIS channel estimation problems.

Few works in the literature address the RIS-assisted channel estimation problem with MC. A channel estimation bound evaluation in the presence of MC was conducted in [18]. The results indicates that the closer integration of RIS unit cells will significantly degrade the channel estimation accuracy. Therefore, MC awareness is emerging as a critical concern in designing channel estimators, particularly for systems with densely integrated RIS designs. Furthermore, [38] suggests
that dictionary learning is an effective tool for handling RIS MC in channel estimation and localization applications when a linear MC model is considered.
4) Beamforming: The RIS beamforming based on the conventional linear model has been extensively studied in the literature. Various approaches have been applied to optimize the RIS phase shifts, such as semidefinite relaxation [39], gradient descent (GD) [40], alternating direction method of multipliers [41], and majorizationminimization [40], [41], among others. More practical designs have also been considered, including dual reflection phase and amplitude variations [42] and designs that account for imperfect channel state information (CSI) [43]. Additionally, active RIS optimization based on the conventional model has been addressed to improve the sum-rate [44] and to account for hardware impairments [45].

The study of MC awareness in RIS beamforming is also in its early stages. By properly adopting the impedance matrix model accounting for the MC and optimizing the RIS phase shift accordingly, [46] demonstrated an enhanced end-toend signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), while [47] obtained an improved sum-rate for multi-user interference channels. A joint active and passive beamforming problem was further studied in [28] for a RIS-assisted downlink and uplink transmissions based on the scattering matrix model. Nonetheless, these works do not consider active RISs, which possess a higher amplification factor and will accentuate the MC effect between RIS elements [19]. Additionally, more effective beamforming algorithms are needed for the scattering matrix-based model. For example, some up-to-date works utilize the GD algorithm to optimize the RIS coefficients based on the scattering matrix model [28]. Although decent performance is achieved, the convergence of GD to the global minimum is not always guaranteed in such non-convex problems, which deserves further investigation.

## B. Contributions

To the best of the authors' knowledge, this is the first work that comprehensively considers both channel estimation and beamforming for an active RIS-assisted communication in the presence of MC among RIS unit cells. Without loss of generality, we consider an uplink multiple-input multipleoutput (MIMO) communication system assisted by an active RIS. We first formulate and solve the channel estimation problem using the electromagnetic-consistent channel model based on the scattering parameter representation, which takes the RIS MC into account. Based on the uplink estimated channel, we first derive the downlink channel and then jointly optimize RIS configuration, base station (BS) precoding, and user equipment (UE) combining, again considering the exact MC-aware model. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

- We formulate and solve the RIS-assisted channel estimation problem in the presence of MC. Specifically, we first demonstrate that the nonlinearity introduced by RIS MC undermines the conventional CS formulation for channel estimation, rendering traditional CSbased estimators infeasible. By carefully manipulating

the observation format based on the MC mechanism, we propose a new CS formulation that accounts for MC without any loss of accuracy. Subsequently, we apply the orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP) algorithm [48] to solve the new CS problem. At this stage, similar to [30], we can estimate an equivalent cascaded channel, which is a coupled Kronecker product of the UE-RIS and RIS-BS subchannels. While the two individual subchannels cannot be separated, we later demonstrate that this equivalent cascaded channel is sufficient for beamforming design.

- We propose a dictionary reduction (DR) strategy to further reduce the complexity of the proposed MC-aware channel estimator by utilizing prior estimation information. While the constructed CS problem accurately accounts for MC, it incurs a dimension lift in the basis space. Specifically, by incorporating MC, the dimension of atoms in the CS dictionary increases from $N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{I}}$ in the conventional solution to $N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}$ (here $N_{\mathrm{B}}$ and $N_{\mathrm{I}}$ respectively denote the sizes of the BS and RIS arrays), hindering the feasibility of our method in large-scale RISs. To address this issue, we propose a two-stage strategy to achieve low-complexity yet accurate estimation. This approach first performs the conventional MCunaware CS estimation to obtain a coarse estimate. Based on this initial estimate, we then design a DR procedure to reduce the dictionary size using the exact MC-aware model. This DR approach can effectively counteract the dimension lift due to the MC effect, achieving complexity comparable to the conventional solution.
- We formulate and solve the joint RIS configuration, BS precoder, and UE combiner optimization problem based on the estimated equivalent cascaded channel. To tackle this complex joint optimization problem, we adopt an alternating optimization strategy, optimizing the three beamformers, i.e., the RIS configuration, BS precoder, and UE combiner alternately. For the BS and UE design, a simple closed-form optimal solution is derived. For the RIS configuration optimization, the nonlinear MC mechanism introduces challenges of intractability and nonconvexity. We first apply the Neumann series expansion to approximate the objective function and reformulate it as a tractable optimization problem. Since the resultant problem remains non-convex, we adopt the successive convex approximation (SCA) framework to solve it. Based on the SCA principle, we propose a specific surrogate function to obtain the descending direction for iteration. A rigorous proof is provided to demonstrate that this surrogate function satisfies the convexity and equalgradient conditions within the SCA framework.
- We validate our methods through extensive numerical simulations. In terms of channel estimation accuracy, the proposed estimation method, even with high MC levels, outperforms the conventional model-based strategy by several dBs and has a similar accuracy of exact model-based procedure but with less complexity (at least $50 \%$ reduction). Moreover, the proposed MC-aware joint beamforming algorithm surpasses the state-of-theart benchmarks, achieving enhanced spectral efficiency.

## C. Organization and Notation

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the channel model while Section III defines the received signal model and formulates the MC-aware channel estimation problem. Section IV details the proposed low-complexity channel estimation solution. Subsequently, we define the joint beamforming problem and outline the alternating optimization strategy in Section V. Given that the BS combiner design is addressed with a closed-form solution immediately following the problem formulation, we delve into the RIS configuration optimization in Section VI. The simulation results are presented in Section VII, and the conclusion and future directions are given in Section VIII.

We use the following notation throughout the paper. Nonbold lower and upper case letters (e.g., $a, A$ ) denote scalars, bold lower case letters (e.g., a) denote vectors, and bold upper case letters (e.g., $\mathbf{A}$ ) denote matrices. We use $A_{i, j}$ to denote the entry at the $i^{\text {th }}$ row and $j^{\text {th }}$ column of the matrix $\mathbf{A}$. In addition, $[\mathbf{A}]_{n,:}$ and $[\mathbf{A}]_{:, m}$ denote $n^{\text {th }}$ row and $m^{\text {th }}$ column of $\mathbf{A}$, respectively. The superscripts $(\cdot)^{\dagger},(\cdot)^{*},(\cdot)^{\mathrm{H}}$, $(\cdot)^{-1}$, and $(\cdot)^{\dagger}$ represent the transpose, conjugate, Hermitian (conjugate transpose), inverse, and pseudo-inverse operators, respectively. For two $M \times N$ matrices $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{B}, \mathbf{A} \otimes \mathbf{B}$ denotes the $M^{2} \times N^{2}$ Kronecker product matrix. Furthermore, $\mathbf{A} \bullet \mathbf{B}$ denotes the $M^{2} \times N$ column-wise Khatri-Rao product matrix, $\mathbf{A} \bullet \mathbf{B}=[[\mathbf{A}]_{:, 1} \otimes[\mathbf{B}]_{:, 1}, \cdots,[\mathbf{A}]_{:, N} \otimes[\mathbf{B}]_{:, N}] ; \odot$ denotes the Hadamard product.

## II. ChAnnel Model

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Fig. 1. Illustration of a RIS-assisted uplink SIMO communication system in the presence of MC between RIS unit cells, where the UE-BS direct channel is assumed to be absent.

Consider an RIS-assisted uplink MIMO communication system, ${ }^{1}$ consisting of an $N_{\mathrm{U}}$-antenna UE, an $N_{\mathrm{B}}$-antenna BS, and an $N_{\mathrm{I}}$-unit cell RIS, as shown in Fig. 1. To focus on RIS reflection, we assume the UE-BS direct channel does not exist. In this work, the RIS is composed of a uniform planar array (UPA) consisting of $N_{\mathrm{I}}=N_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{b}} \times N_{\mathrm{I}}^{c}$ tightlypacked unit cells, where the superscripts ' $h$ ' and ' $v$ ' denote the horizontal and vertical dimensions, respectively. The same assumption is applied for the BS and UE, i.e., $N_{\mathrm{B}}=N_{\mathrm{B}}^{\mathrm{b}} \times N_{\mathrm{B}}^{\mathrm{c}}$ and $N_{\mathrm{U}}=N_{\mathrm{U}}^{\mathrm{b}} \times N_{\mathrm{U}}^{\mathrm{c}}$. In the following subsections, we first detail the individual UE-RIS and RIS-BS subchannels, and then elaborate on how the MC between RIS unit cells reshapes the overall cascaded channel.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Typically, channel estimation is performed for the uplink channels, and the downlink channels are obtained based on channel reciprocity [32].

## A. The Channel Between UE and RIS

Assuming a far-field propagation scenario, the highfrequency narrow-band frequency-domain channel from the UE to the RIS, $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IU}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}} \times N_{\mathrm{U}}}$, is defined as [31]

$$
\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IU}}=\sqrt{\frac{N_{\mathrm{I}} N_{\mathrm{U}}}{L_{\mathrm{U}}}} \sum_{\ell=1}^{L_{\mathrm{U}}} \alpha_{\ell} \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}\left(\phi_{\ell}\right) \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{U}}^{\top}\left(\varphi_{\ell}\right)
$$

where $\alpha_{\ell} \in \mathbb{C}$ denotes the complex channel gain, $\varphi_{\ell} \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ the angle-of-departure (AoD) at the UE, $\phi_{\ell} \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ the angle-ofarrival (AoA) at the RIS, and $\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{U}}\left(\varphi_{\ell}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{U}}}$ and $\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}\left(\phi_{\ell}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}}}$ are the array response vector (ARV) at the UE and RIS corresponding to $\varphi_{\ell}$ and $\phi_{\ell}$, respectively. Note that each AoA and AoD comprises an azimuth and an elevation component, e.g., $\phi_{\ell}=\left[\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{ex}}, \phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{el}}\right]^{\top} .^{2}$ Under a UPA setup, the ARV at the RIS can be expressed as [36]

$$
\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}\left(\phi_{\ell}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N_{\mathrm{I}}}} e^{-j 2 \pi \phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{b}} \mathbf{n}\left(N_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{b}}\right)} \otimes e^{-j 2 \pi \phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{e}} \mathbf{n}\left(N_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{e}}\right)}
$$

where $\mathbf{n}(N)=[0,1, \ldots, N-1]^{\top}$, and $\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{b}}$ and $\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{e}}$ are the spatial angles corresponding to the horizontal and vertical dimensions, respectively. Assuming the UPA is deployed on the YZ-plane of the RIS's body coordinate system, we obtain $\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{b}} \triangleq d_{\mathrm{I}} \sin \left(\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{ex}}\right) \sin \left(\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{el}}\right) / \lambda$ and $\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{e}} \triangleq d_{\mathrm{I}} \cos \left(\phi_{\ell}^{\mathrm{el}}\right) / \lambda$, where $\lambda$ is the wavelength of the operating frequency, $f_{o}$, and $d_{\mathrm{I}}$ is the inter-element spacing of the RIS. In addition, $L_{\mathrm{U}}$ in (1) is the number of paths between the UE and RIS, where $\ell=1$ stands for the line-of-sight (LoS) path and $\ell=2, \ldots, L_{\mathrm{U}}$ correspond to $L_{\mathrm{U}}-1$ non-line-of-sight (NLoS) paths.

By concatenating all the ARVs into a matrix form, (1) can be written as [30], [33]

$$
\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IU}}=\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\varphi})
$$

where we define $\boldsymbol{\phi}=\left[\phi_{1}^{\top}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\phi}_{L_{\mathrm{I}}}^{\top}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{2 L_{\mathrm{U}}}, \boldsymbol{\varphi}=$ $\left[\boldsymbol{\varphi}_{1}^{\top}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\varphi}_{L_{\mathrm{U}}}^{\top}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{2 L_{\mathrm{U}}}, \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}(\boldsymbol{\phi})=\left[\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}\left(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{1}\right), \cdots, \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}\left(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{L_{\mathrm{U}}}\right)\right] \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}} \times L_{\mathrm{U}}}, \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi})=\left[\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{U}}\left(\boldsymbol{\varphi}_{1}\right), \cdots, \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{U}}\left(\boldsymbol{\varphi}_{L_{\mathrm{U}}}\right)\right] \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{U}} \times L_{\mathrm{U}}}$, and $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}}=\sqrt{N_{\mathrm{I}} N_{\mathrm{U}} / L_{\mathrm{U}}} \operatorname{diag}\left(\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{L_{\mathrm{U}}}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{L_{\mathrm{U}} \times L_{\mathrm{U}}}$ is the beamspace channel matrix.

## B. The Channel Between RIS and BS

Similarly, the frequency-domain channel from the RIS to the BS, $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} \times N_{\mathrm{I}}}$, can be expressed as [31]

$$
\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}}=\sqrt{\frac{N_{\mathrm{I}} N_{\mathrm{B}}}{L_{\mathrm{B}}}} \sum_{\ell=1}^{L_{\mathrm{B}}} \rho_{\ell} \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{B}}\left(\vartheta_{\ell}\right) \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\ell}\right)
$$

where $L_{\mathrm{B}}$ is the number of paths between the RIS and BS, $\rho_{\ell} \in \mathbb{C}$ denotes the complex channel gain, $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\ell} \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ denotes the AoD at the RIS, $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}_{\ell} \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ denotes the AoA at the BS, and $\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{B}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}}}$ and $\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}}}$ denote the ARVs of the antenna arrays at the BS and RIS, respectively. We denote $d_{\mathrm{B}}$ as the inter-element spacing of the BS. Analogously, by concatenating all the BS/RIS ARVs and the channel coefficients in a matrix form, the channel $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}}$ can be equivalently written as [30], [33]

$$
\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}}=\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

[^0]where we define $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\left[\boldsymbol{\vartheta}_{1}^{\top}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}_{L_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\top}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{2 L_{\mathrm{B}}}, \boldsymbol{\theta}=$ $\left[\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{\top}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{L_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\top}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{2 L_{\mathrm{B}}}, \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\left[\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{B}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}_{1}\right), \cdots, \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{B}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}_{L_{\mathrm{B}}}\right)\right] \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} \times L_{\mathrm{B}}}, \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left[\mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}\right), \cdots, \mathbf{a}_{\mathrm{I}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{L_{\mathrm{B}}}\right)\right] \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}} \times L_{\mathrm{B}}}$, and the beamspace channel matrix $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}=$ $\sqrt{N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{I}} / L_{\mathrm{B}}} \operatorname{diag}\left(\rho_{1}, \cdots, \rho_{L_{\mathrm{B}}}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{L_{\mathrm{B}} \times L_{\mathrm{B}}}$.

## C. Conventional Cascaded Channel Model

We elaborate on the channel model with the training stage as the background. During training, the active RIS employs a set of different amplitude and phase configurations, which leads to a different cascaded channel matrix for different transmissions (more details in Section III-A). ${ }^{3}$ Since we have assumed the UE-BS direct link to be absent, the conventional RIS-assisted cascaded channel model corresponding to the $m_{\mathrm{I}}{ }^{\text {th }}$ training configuration-without accounting for mutual coupling between RIS unit cells-can be written as [7], [9], [10], [19], [30], [32], [33]

$$
\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{cv}}^{m_{\mathrm{I}}}=\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}} \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{\mathrm{I}}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IU}}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{\mathrm{I}}}=\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{m_{\mathrm{I}}}\right)$, and $\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{m_{\mathrm{I}}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}}}$ is the vector of RIS reflection coefficients at the $m_{\mathrm{I}}{ }^{\text {th }}$ training configuration, $m_{\mathrm{I}}=1,2, \ldots, M_{\mathrm{I}}$, and $M_{\mathrm{I}}$ denotes the number of random RIS configurations during the training. The reflection coefficient of the $i^{\text {th }}$ RIS unit cell can be expressed as $\gamma_{m_{\mathrm{I}}, i}=$ $a_{i} e^{j \vartheta_{i}}$, where $a_{i} \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$represents the amplification factor and $\vartheta_{i} \in(0,2 \pi]$ denotes the phase shift. Both $a_{i}$ and $\vartheta_{i}$ are reconfigurable; however, they are usually dependent on each other [49]. For nearly-passive RISs, $a_{i} \in(0,1]$, as RISs passively reflect signals without power amplification. When reflection-type amplifiers are incorporated, which is known as active RISs, signal amplification is enabled and $a_{i}>1$ is available [12], [13], [50]. It has been shown in [19] that a higher amplification factor of RIS accentuates the impact of mutual coupling between RIS unit cells. Hence, this work employs the active RIS setup to comprehensively evaluate the impact of MC and propose the corresponding solutions.

By examining (6), it is evident that the received signal at the BS is a linear combination of signals reflected from each RIS unit cell. This model assumes that each RIS unit cell reflects incident EM waves independently without any interaction, thereby neglecting the MC effect. In scenarios where strong MC exists among RIS unit cells, this assumption can lead to significant model mismatch and pose challenges for applications such as channel estimation [18], ultimately degrading overall communication performance.

## D. Mutual Coupling-Aware Channel Model

Although the MC effect is sufficiently weak and can be reasonably omitted in many cases, recent studies have shown that the MC effect between RIS unit cells is pronounced when they are tightly integrated (e.g. holographic RIS/MIMO [14]-[16]) or the amplification factor increases (e.g., active RISs [19], [50]). Based on the S-parameter multiport network theory,

[^1]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ We define the elevation angle as the angle between the direction of interest and the positive Z-axis, which is also called the inclination angle.

[^1]:    ${ }^{3}$ In the data transmission stage, the RIS response is set to a fixed optimized configuration determined through the beamforming process, as will be presented in Section V and Section VI.

a mutual coupling-aware communication model has been recently derived and validated [25], [26], [29], which will be adopted in this paper. To focus on the RIS, this work neglects the mutual coupling at the BS and UE.
By incorporating the mutual coupling effect within the RIS response, the channel model (6) is reformulated as [25]-[29]

$$
\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{m} 1}=\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IU}}
$$

where $\mathbf{S} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}} \times N_{\mathrm{I}}}$ is the scattering matrix within the RIS unit cells, characterizing the mutual coupling effect. Specifically, $S_{i, j}$ denotes the scattering parameter between the $i^{\text {th }}$ and $j^{\text {th }}$ unit cells of the RIS, which is defined as $S_{i, j}=\left.\frac{V_{i}^{\text {out }}}{V_{j}^{\text {in }}}\right|_{V_{2}^{\text {in }}=0, \forall k \neq j}[22]$, where $V_{j}^{\text {in }}$ denotes the voltage wave driving at the $j^{\text {th }}$ unit cell and $V_{i}^{\text {out }}$ denotes the voltage wave coming out from the $i^{\text {th }}$ unit cell. The initial derivation of model (7) can be found in [51], with the complete derivation and analysis available in, e.g., [24], [26], [27]. Additionally, an experimental validation of (7) on a real RIS prototype has been reported in [29]. For clarity, we refer to (6) as the conventional model and (7) as the exact model. Note that by setting $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{0}$, the exact model reduces to the conventional model.

Remark 1: It can be inferred from (7) that with the same level of MC, higher amplification of the RIS can exacerbate the impact of MC. This is because the scattering matrix $\mathbf{S}$ is superposed on the inversion of $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}$. Hence, the greater the values in $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}$, the more significantly its inversion can be impacted by $\mathbf{S}$.
To verify the inference in Remark 1, Fig. 2 depicts the normalized beam pattern reflected from RIS when a directional beam $\gamma=a \mathbf{a}_{1}^{*}(\theta) \odot \mathbf{a}_{1}^{*}(\phi)$ is used in a 16 -element uniform linear array (ULA) layout RIS. This evaluation is based on the scattering parameters measured in [29]. As illustrated, when the RIS amplification is low ( $a=2$ ), the impact of MC on the RIS radiation pattern is weak and negligible. However, when the RIS amplification is enlarged ( $a=5$ ), we observe that the same MC can more significantly distort the beam pattern. Furthermore, we also observe that the severity of the impact of MC varies across different AoDs, meaning that the impact of MC is direction-selective. Nevertheless, the principle revealed in Remark 1 holds across different directions.

## III. Signal Model and CS Formulation
## A. The Received Signal

For illustrative convenience, this work assumes that the BS is equipped with a single radio frequency chain (RFC) and employs a fully digital beamforming scheme. ${ }^{4}$ We start the training procedure by sending pilots-through the uplink channel-utilizing training beams and adjusting the amplitudes and phase shifts of the RIS elements within a time coherence block divided into multiple subframes. On the RIS side, this is achieved using $M_{\mathrm{I}}$ configurations. Each subframe corresponds to one random RIS phase matrix. During each

[^0]![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Fig. 2. Normalized beam pattern of the RIS reflection using the directional beam $\boldsymbol{\gamma}=a \mathbf{a}_{1}^{*}(\theta) \odot \mathbf{a}_{1}^{*}(\phi)$ in a 16-element ULA layout RIS. Here, we test over different values of the RIS amplification factor $a=\{2,5\}$, assuming all unit cells maintain the same amplification factor. The scattering matrix $\mathbf{S}$ is assigned based on the measured data in [29].
subframe, while the RIS holds the configuration constant, both the UE and BS utilize various training beams with total training measurements of $M_{\mathrm{B}} M_{\mathrm{I}}$. We assume that the number of transmitted pilots and precoding training beams equals the total number of combining training beams, which is $M_{\mathrm{B}}$ per subframe. Specifically, for the $m_{\mathrm{I}}{ }^{\text {th }}$ RIS configuration, the UE transmits $M_{\mathrm{B}}$ pilots using random precoding training beams $\mathbf{f}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{U}}}$, while the BS records $M_{\mathrm{B}}$ received pilots through random combining beams $\mathbf{w}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}}}, m_{\mathrm{B}}=1,2, \ldots, M_{\mathrm{B}}$. Note that we assume, during the uplink training, $\left\|\mathbf{f}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}\right\|_{2}^{2}=P_{\mathrm{U}}$ and $\left\|\mathbf{w}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}\right\|_{2}^{2}=1$, where $P_{\mathrm{U}}$ is the transmit power at the UE. Moreover, the $M_{\mathrm{B}}$ precoding and combining beams remain fixed for different RIS configurations.

Based on the exact model (7), the received signal for the $\left(m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}\right)$ measurements is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
y_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}} & =\mathbf{w}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{m_{\mathrm{I}}} \mathbf{f}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}} x_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}+\omega_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}} \\
& =x_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}\left(\mathbf{f}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{T}} \otimes \mathbf{w}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{H}}\right) \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{m_{\mathrm{I}}}\right)+\omega_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}} \\
& =x_{m_{\mathrm{B}}} \mathbf{p}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{T}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{m_{\mathrm{I}}}\right)+\omega_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $x_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}$ is the transmitted training pilot and $\omega_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}$ denotes the total additive noise. Here, we assume $\mathbb{E}\left[x_{m_{\mathrm{B}}} x_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{H}}\right]=$ 1. We denote $\mathbf{p}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}} \triangleq\left(\mathbf{f}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{T}} \otimes \mathbf{w}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{H}}\right)^{\mathrm{T}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}}}$ in (8). Based on the propagation model of active RISs, the total noise $\omega_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}$ can be expressed as [13], [50]

$$
\omega_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}=\mathbf{w}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{\mathrm{I}}}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{\omega}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}^{\mathrm{I}}+\boldsymbol{\omega}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}^{\mathrm{B}}\right)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}^{\mathrm{I}} \sim \mathcal{C N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma_{\mathrm{I}}^{2} \mathbf{I}_{N_{\mathrm{I}}}\right)$ is the thermal noise at the active RIS and $\boldsymbol{\omega}_{m_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{\mathrm{I}}}^{\mathrm{B}} \sim \mathcal{C N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma_{\mathrm{B}}^{2} \mathbf{I}_{N_{\mathrm{B}}}\right)$ is the thermal noise at the BS.

We collect all the received signals over $m_{\mathrm{B}}$ and $m_{\mathrm{I}}$, and denote the matrix of the resultant received signals after taking away the impact of $x_{m_{\mathrm{I}}}$ using a matched filter [36], [37] as $\mathbf{Y} \in \mathbb{C}^{M_{\mathrm{B}} \times M_{\mathrm{I}}}$, whose each column is given by

$$
[\mathbf{Y}]_{, m_{\mathrm{I}}}=\mathbf{P} \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{m_{\mathrm{I}}}\right)+\bar{\omega}_{m_{\mathrm{I}}}
$$

where $\mathbf{P}=\left[\mathbf{p}_{1}, \mathbf{p}_{2}, \ldots, \mathbf{p}_{M_{\mathrm{B}}}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{C}^{M_{\mathrm{B}} \times N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}}}$ and $\overline{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{m_{1}}=$ $\left[\omega_{1, m_{1}}, \omega_{2, m_{1}}, \ldots, \omega_{M_{\mathrm{B}}, m_{1}}\right]^{\top} \in \mathbb{C}^{M_{\mathrm{B}}}$. In the following subsections, we present some useful mathematical transformations based on the nature of the received signals to reveal a CSlike structure, thereby facilitating the later development of the channel estimation method. We first recap the conventional formulation without MC, and then propose a new formulation that accurately accounts for MC.

## B. The CS Formulation Based on the Conventional Model

Based on the conventional model (6) that does not account for MC, one can rewrite (10), by setting $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{0}$, as

$$
\left[\mathbf{Y}_{\mathrm{cv}}\right]_{:, m_{1}}=\mathbf{P} \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{cv}}^{m_{1}}\right)+\overline{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{m_{1}}
$$

where we denote the received signal based on the conventional model as $\mathbf{Y}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ to distinguish it from the exact received signal $\mathbf{Y}$ defined in (10). Utilizing (3) and (5), we can express the term $\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{cv}}^{m_{1}}\right)$ in (11) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{cv}}^{m_{1}}\right)=\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{II}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\varphi})\right) \\
& =\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}) \otimes \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right) \operatorname{vec}\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}}\right) \\
& =\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}}^{\top} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right) \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}(\boldsymbol{\phi})\right) \\
& =\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \otimes \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right) \operatorname{vec}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}}\right) \\
& =\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \bullet \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right) \boldsymbol{\gamma}_{m_{1}} \\
& =\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{cv}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{\top} \boldsymbol{\gamma}_{m_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}}=\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}}^{\top}$ since it is a diagonal matrix, $\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \triangleq$ $\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}) \otimes \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{B}} \times L_{\mathrm{U}} L_{\mathrm{B}}}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{II}}^{\mathrm{cv}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \triangleq$ $\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \bullet \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}} \times L_{\mathrm{U}} L_{\mathrm{B}}}$. An important observation is that (12) holds because $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}}$ is a diagonal matrix. This is an essential difference between the conventional and exact models that will be derived later in Section III-C.

Furthermore, we define the conventional equivalent cascaded channel and its vectorized version as [7], [30]

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}} \triangleq \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{II}}^{\mathrm{cv}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{B}} \times N_{\mathrm{I}}} \\
& \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}}\right)=\underbrace{\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{cv}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \otimes \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \operatorname{vec}\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)}_{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{cv}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

By substituting (13) and (14) into (11), we can write $\left[\mathbf{Y}_{\mathrm{cv}}\right]_{:, m_{1}}$ as

$$
\left[\mathbf{Y}_{\mathrm{cv}}\right]_{:, m_{1}}=\mathbf{P} \mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}} \boldsymbol{\gamma}_{m_{1}}+\overline{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{m_{1}}
$$

and we obtain, after collecting all of the measurements, the following observation model [7], [30], [31]

$$
\mathbf{Y}_{\mathrm{cv}}=\mathbf{P} \mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}} \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{cv}}+\boldsymbol{\Omega}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{cv}} \triangleq\left[\gamma_{1}, \gamma_{2}, \cdots, \gamma_{M_{\mathrm{I}}}\right] \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}} \times M_{\mathrm{I}}}$ and $\boldsymbol{\Omega} \triangleq$ $\left[\overline{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{2}, \ldots, \overline{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{M_{\mathrm{I}}}\right] \in \mathbb{C}^{M_{\mathrm{B}} \times M_{\mathrm{I}}}$. By applying a vectorization operation to (17) and substituting (15), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{Y}_{\mathrm{cv}}-\boldsymbol{\Omega}\right) & =\left(\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{cv}}^{\top} \otimes \mathbf{P}\right) \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}}\right) \\
& =\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\mathrm{cv}} \mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{cv}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we define $\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\mathrm{cv}} \triangleq \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{cv}}^{\top} \otimes \mathbf{P} \in \mathbb{C}^{M_{\mathrm{B}} M_{\mathrm{I}} \times N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}}}$ as the known measurement matrix, and $\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ is the basis matrix define in (15). Here, it is clear that (18) is a typical CS problem structure [53]. By carefully designing the dictionary $\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ and
adopting sparse CS estimation algorithms, we can recover the equivalent cascaded channel $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ based on the received signal $\mathbf{Y}_{\mathrm{cv}}$, since $\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}}\right)=\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{cv}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)$.

## C. The CS Formulation Based on the Exact Model

Now let's consider the case with MC. Due to the existence of matrix $\mathbf{S}$, the RIS response $\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}$ is no longer a diagonal matrix. Thus, (12) is no longer holds. The following derivation aims to formulate an accurate CS structure accounting for MC starting from (10). Following the same steps in deriving (13) in Section III-B, we can express the term $\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{m_{1}}\right)$ in (8) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{m_{1}}\right) & =\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \check{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{m_{1}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\varphi})\right) \\
& =\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right) \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \boldsymbol{\xi}_{m_{1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{II}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \triangleq\left(\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\boldsymbol{\top}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \otimes \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\boldsymbol{\top}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{\boldsymbol{\top}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2} \times L_{\mathrm{U}} L_{\mathrm{B}}}$ and, for notational convenience, we denote $\boldsymbol{\xi}_{m_{1}} \triangleq \operatorname{vec}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{m_{1}}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}}$ with $\check{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{m_{1}} \triangleq\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{m_{1}}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}$. The difference lies in the last two terms of (19) compared to (13), which arises from the non-diagonality of the RIS response matrix.

We define the exact equivalent cascaded channel and its vectorized version

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}} \triangleq \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right) \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{II}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{B}} \times N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}} \\
& \operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}\right)=\underbrace{\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{II}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \otimes \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \operatorname{vec}\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)}_{\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{mc}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, based on (10), we have

$$
\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{P} \mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}} \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{mc}}+\boldsymbol{\Omega}
$$

where we define $\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{mc}} \triangleq\left[\boldsymbol{\xi}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\xi}_{2}, \cdots, \boldsymbol{\xi}_{M_{\mathrm{I}}}\right] \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2} \times M_{\mathrm{I}}}$. By vectorizing (22) and substituting (21), we have

$$
\operatorname{vec}(\mathbf{Y}-\boldsymbol{\Omega})=\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\mathrm{mc}} \mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{mc}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \otimes \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}}\right)
$$

which follows the typical structure of the CS problem [53]. Here, $\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\mathrm{mc}} \triangleq\left(\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\top} \otimes \mathbf{P}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{M_{\mathrm{B}} M_{\mathrm{I}} \times N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}}$ is the measurement matrix, and $\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ is the basis matrix defined in (21).

Remark 2: Comparing (18) and (23) reveals that accounting for MC results in a dimensional increase in both the measurement and basis matrices. Specifically, the dimension of $\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ is $M_{\mathrm{B}} M_{\mathrm{I}} \times N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}}$, while the dimension of $\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ expands to $M_{\mathrm{B}} M_{\mathrm{I}} \times N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}$. Moreover, the dimension of the atoms in $\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ is $N_{\mathrm{I}}$ times that of $\mathbf{D}_{\mathrm{cv}}$. The enhanced accuracy comes at the expense of higher complexity. Given the large number of elements in an RIS (and consequently, a large $N_{\mathrm{I}}$ ), such an increase in dimensionality can render CS solutions infeasible in practice. We will show in Section IV-B that applying the proposed DR strategy can effectively mitigate this complexity issue from an algorithmic perspective.

## IV. MC-Aware RIS Channel Estimation
## A. Quantized Dictionaries and CS-Based Channel Estimation

Since the cascaded channel's parameters are unknown, we approximate the channel based on pre-determined dictionaries and apply on-grid CS techniques to solve (23) and (18). Following angular quantization to a grid of size $G_{i}=G_{i}^{\mathrm{h}} G_{i}^{\mathrm{v}}$, the

discrete array response matrices $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\psi}) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{i} \times G_{i}}$, recalling that $i \in\{\mathrm{U}, \mathrm{B}, \mathrm{I}\}$, as

$$
\left[\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\psi})\right]_{:, g_{i}^{\mathrm{B}}+\left(g_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}-1\right) G_{i}^{\mathrm{b}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N_{i}}} e^{-j 2 \pi \beta_{g_{i}^{\mathrm{B}}^{\mathrm{B}}}^{\mathrm{b}} \mathbf{n}\left[N_{i}^{\mathrm{b}}\right]} \otimes e^{-j 2 \pi \beta_{g_{i}^{\mathrm{C}}^{\mathrm{C}}}^{\mathrm{C}} \mathbf{n}\left[N_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}\right]}
$$

where the discrete spatial angles, $\varepsilon \in\{\mathrm{h}, \mathrm{v}\}$, are defined [36]

$$
\beta_{g_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}}^{\mathrm{c}}=\frac{2 d_{i}}{\lambda G_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}}\left(g_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}-\frac{G_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}+1}{2}\right), g_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}=1, \cdots, G_{i}^{\mathrm{c}} ; G_{i}^{\mathrm{c}} \geq N_{i}^{\mathrm{c}}
$$

According to (15) and (21), we construct the conventional and exact dictionary matrices as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{cv}}=\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}^{\mathrm{cv}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \otimes \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}} \times G_{\mathrm{B}} G_{\mathrm{U}} G_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}} \\
& \tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{mc}}=\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \otimes \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2} \times G_{\mathrm{B}} G_{\mathrm{U}} G_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}^{\mathrm{cv}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \triangleq\left(\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \bullet \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{\top}, \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta}) \triangleq$ $\left(\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \otimes \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)^{\top}$, and $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{UB}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \triangleq \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{U}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}) \otimes \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$. Following [30, Proposition 1], the Khatri-Rao-based dictionary $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}^{\mathrm{cv}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta})$ of conventional structure (25) contains significant redundancy, with $G_{\mathrm{B}} G_{\mathrm{U}} G_{\mathrm{I}} \leq \bar{G}_{\mathrm{cv}} \ll G_{\mathrm{B}} G_{\mathrm{U}} G_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}$ denotes the number of distinct columns. However, the Kroneckerbased dictionary $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}, \boldsymbol{\theta})$ of exact structure (26) does not pose similar redundancy, i.e. $\bar{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}=G_{\mathrm{B}} G_{\mathrm{U}} G_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}$. Thus, we define $\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{cv}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}} \times \bar{G}_{\mathrm{cv}}}$ and $\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{mc}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} N_{\mathrm{U}} N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2} \times \bar{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}}$ as the unique dictionaries that contain only distinct columns. This implies that the exact dictionary $\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ not only has a higher dimensionality of atoms but also a greater number of atoms.

By substituting $\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{cv}} / \tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ into (18)/(23), we can get the sparse formulation for the conventional/exact model as

$$
\mathbf{y}=\operatorname{vec}(\mathbf{Y})=\boldsymbol{\Xi}_{\chi} \hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\chi}+\operatorname{vec}(\boldsymbol{\Omega})
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\Xi}_{\chi}=\boldsymbol{\Psi}_{\chi} \tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\chi} \in \mathbb{C}^{M_{\mathrm{B}} M_{\mathrm{I}} \times \bar{G}_{\chi}}$ is the sensing matrix and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\chi} \in \mathbb{C}^{\bar{G}_{\chi}}$ is a sparse vector, $\chi \in\{\mathrm{cv}, \mathrm{mc}\}$. Here, $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\chi}$ can be estimated using the CS algorithm such as OMP [48]. Then the equivalent cascaded channel $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}} / \mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ can be recovered based on (15)/(21). Nonetheless, the conventional model-based solution suffers from significant model mismatch due to the neglect of MC, while the exact model-based solution involves a dimensional lift (as seen when comparing the dimensions of the dictionaries $\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ and $\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ ). In the following subsection, we propose a two-stage compromise estimation strategy that enjoys the advantages of both methods.

## B. Proposed Two-Stage Channel Estimation Strategy

Before presenting our estimation strategy, we elaborate on the motivation behind it. As discussed in Section II-D, the exact model simplifies to the conventional model when $\mathbf{S}=\mathbf{0}$. Although this simplification introduces model mismatch, we can leverage its low complexity to obtain a coarse estimate as prior information for the exact model-based method. This, in turn, helps reduce the complexity of the exact CS solution. Building on this idea, we propose a two-stage estimation algorithm outlined in Algorithm 1. Specifically, the first stage estimates $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ by applying OMP to (27) with $\chi=\mathrm{cv}$. In the second stage, we utilize the prior information $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ and

1) Coarse Estimation: In the first stage, we apply the OMP algorithm to estimate $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ depending on $\boldsymbol{\Xi}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ and $\tilde{L}$, as presented in Step 1 of Algorithm $1 .{ }^{6}$ The estimated sparse vector $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ is filled based on the detected support $\Upsilon^{\mathrm{cv}}$.
2) Refined Estimation: In the second stage, we perform exact CS estimation with prior information of a coarse estimate. ${ }^{7}$ In step 2 of Algorithm 1, we construct $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{I}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{I}} \times \tilde{L}}$, a matrix consisting of the columns of $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}^{\mathrm{cv}}$ corresponding to the support $\Upsilon^{\mathrm{cv}}$ obtained in step 1 . This dictionary represents the spatial angles to limit the search space over and is the first input for the proposed DR algorithm. The second input is the dictionary $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}$. We apply the proposed DR algorithm in step 3, where the idea is to extract only a small number of columns from $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{II}}$ that were used to get $\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ (steps 69 ). The selected $G_{\mathrm{DR}}$ columns have the highest correlation with $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{I}}$ (from step 2) and correspond to the most probable spatial angles where the channel is expected to be. We define $G_{\mathrm{DR}}=\rho_{\mathrm{DR}} \tilde{G}_{\mathrm{cv}} / G_{\mathrm{B}} G_{\mathrm{U}} \ll G_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}$ for the proposed approach to be less complex yet accurate. Here, $\rho_{\mathrm{DR}} \in(0,1]$ is defined as the $D R$ factor. In step 4 , by using $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{DR}}$ of step 3 , we compute the DR sensing matrix to be later used in step 5 where we apply the OMP algorithm. The output $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ is an estimate of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ defined in (27). Finally, the exact equivalent cascaded channel $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ can be recovered as $\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}\right)=\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{\mathrm{DR}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$.

This section analyzes and addresses the downlink beamforming problem given an exact equivalent cascaded channel estimate obtained via the uplink channel estimator described
