## A. Problem Formulation

To maintain consistency with the notation in previous sections, we continue to denote the downlink precoder at the BS as $\mathbf{w} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}}}$ and the combiner at the UE as $\mathbf{f} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{U}}}$, both being digital. Hence, the downlink signal model is written as

$$
s_{\mathrm{U}}=\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}} \mathbf{w} s_{\mathrm{B}}+\omega
$$

where $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}=\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IU}}^{\mathrm{T}}, \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}}=\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{BI}}^{\mathrm{T}}, s_{\mathrm{B}}$ and $s_{\mathrm{U}}$ are the transmitted and received symbols, respectively, and $\omega$ denotes the noise. Specifically, $\omega=\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{\omega}^{\mathrm{I}}+\boldsymbol{\omega}^{\mathrm{U}}\right)$, where $\boldsymbol{\omega}^{\mathrm{I}} \sim \mathcal{C N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{I}_{N_{\mathrm{I}}}\right)$ represents the thermal noise at the active RIS and $\boldsymbol{\omega}^{\mathrm{U}} \sim \mathcal{C N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \sigma_{\mathrm{U}}^{2} \mathbf{I}_{N_{\mathrm{U}}}\right)$ is the thermal noise at the UE.

We assume $\mathbb{E}\left[s_{\mathrm{B}} s_{\mathrm{B}}^{\mathrm{H}}\right]=1$ and $\|\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2} \leq P_{\mathrm{B}}$, where $P_{\mathrm{B}}$ constrains the maximum transmit power at the BS. As a result, the receive SNR can be calculated as [13]

$$
\mathrm{SNR}=\frac{\left|\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}} \mathbf{w}\right|^{2}}{\|\mathbf{f}\|_{2}^{2} \sigma_{\mathrm{U}}^{2}+\left\|\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}\right\|_{2}^{2} \sigma_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}}
$$

Note that the denominator here contains two terms of noise power: (i) the power of noise generated at the UE itself, computed as $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{2}^{2} \sigma_{\mathrm{U}}^{2}$, and (ii) the power of noise generated at the active RIS, which is amplified, propagated, and received by the UE, computed as $\left\|\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}\right\|_{2}^{2} \sigma_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}$.

Remark 3: In far-field scenarios, the additional noise term $\left\|\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}\right\|_{2}^{2} \sigma_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}$ due to active RIS is usually negligible compared to the noise level at the receiver UE $\|\mathbf{f}\|_{2}^{2} \sigma_{\mathrm{U}}^{2}$.

Fig. 3 provides a numerical validation of Remark 3. Even with an extremely large RIS amplification factor, e.g., $a=64$, the additional noise power remains several orders of magnitude weaker than the noise power at the receiver. It is worth noting that a typical phase-reconfigurable reflection amplifier can
achieve a maximum performance of approximately $a=10$ only [12, Fig. 9]. Consequently, the additional noise introduced by the active RIS can be safely neglected in far-field scenarios, allowing the receive SNR to be simplified as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{SNR} & \approx \frac{\left|\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}} \mathbf{w}\right|^{2}}{\|\mathbf{f}\|_{2}^{2} \sigma_{\mathrm{U}}^{2}} \\
& =\left|\frac{\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}}}{\|\mathbf{f}\|_{2}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}} \mathbf{w}\right|^{2} / \sigma_{\mathrm{U}}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, the joint beamforming problem can be formulated as

$$
\max _{\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{w}, \gamma} \overbrace{\left\|\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\gamma)^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}} \mathbf{w}\right|^{2}}^{\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}}
$$

s.t. $\quad\|\mathbf{f}\|_{2}^{2}=1,\|\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2} \leq P_{\mathrm{B}},\|\gamma\|_{2}^{2} \leq A$.

Here, we use a value $A>N_{\mathrm{I}}$ to constrain the amplification vector $\gamma$ of the active RIS, which corresponds to the maximum radiated power of the first-order radiation when a unit-power far-field signal impinges on the active RIS. For notational convenience, we define $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\gamma)^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}} \triangleq \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UIB}}$. The problem is that $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UIB}}$ is unavailable. Instead, we only have the uplink exact equivalent cascaded channel $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{UL}}$. The following steps establish connections between them.

According to (20), we have $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{UL}}=\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{T}}(\boldsymbol{\phi}) \otimes$ $\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{T}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$. Now, we define the downlink exact equivalent cascaded channel as $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{DL}} \triangleq \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{B}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{T}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \otimes$ $\mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{U}}(\boldsymbol{\varphi}) \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\mathrm{IU}} \mathbf{A}_{\mathrm{I}}^{\mathrm{T}}(\boldsymbol{\phi})$, which can be obtained from $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{UL}}$ by rearranging the layout of its entries. Then, we have

$$
\operatorname{vec}\left(\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UIB}}\right)=\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{DL}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\left(\operatorname{diag}(\gamma)^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}\right)
$$

A proof of this relationship is given in Appendix A. This relationship means that we can obtain the cascaded channel $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UIB}}$ from the previously estimated uplink equivalent channel $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{UL}}$, and thus the joint beamforming problem (31) can be solved without the knowledge about the individual subchannels $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UI}}$ and $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{IB}}$.

In the following, we solve (31) using an alternating optimization approach. At each iteration, we first optimize $\{\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{w}\}$ while keeping $\gamma$ fixed, and then optimize $\gamma$ while keeping $\{\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{w}\}$ fixed. These two steps are repeated iteratively until the objective function converges.

## B. BS Precoding and UE Combining: A Closed-Form Solution

Given a feasible RIS configuration $\gamma$, we can obtain $\mathbf{H}_{\text {UIB }}$ according to (32). Then, problem (31) is reduced to

$$
\max _{\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{w}}\left|\mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UIB}} \mathbf{w}\right|^{2}, \quad \text { s.t. }\|\mathbf{f}\|_{2}^{2}=1,\|\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2} \leq P_{\mathrm{B}}
$$

This problem can be solved by simply applying singular value decomposition (SVD) to $\mathbf{H}_{\text {UIB }}$. Let $\mathbf{u}_{\max }$ and $\mathbf{v}_{\max }$ denote the left- and right-singular vectors corresponding to the maximum singular value of $\mathbf{H}_{\mathrm{UIB}}$, respectively. The solution of (33) is given by $\mathbf{f}_{\star}=\mathbf{u}_{\max }$ and $\mathbf{w}_{\star}=\sqrt{P_{\mathrm{B}}} \mathbf{v}_{\max }$.

## C. RIS Beamforming: Approximation and Reformulation

Based on (32), we can rewrite the objective function of (31) as $\left|\left(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{T}} \otimes \mathbf{f}^{\mathrm{H}}\right) \mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{DE}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\left(\operatorname{diag}\left(\gamma\right)^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}\right)\right|^{2}$. Given a pair of feasible $\{\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{w}\}$ and defining $\mathbf{t} \triangleq\left(\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}^{\mathrm{DE}}\right)^{\mathrm{T}}\left(\mathbf{w} \otimes \mathbf{f}^{*}\right) \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{f}}^{2} \times 1}$, the joint problem (31) is reduced into

$$
\begin{aligned}
\max _{\gamma} & \left|\mathbf{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\left(\operatorname{diag}\left(\gamma\right)^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}\right)\right|^{2} \\
\text { s.t. } & \|\gamma\|_{2}^{2} \leq A
\end{aligned}
$$

The matrix inversion in the objective function poses significant challenges for optimization. To circumvent this intractable process, we leverage the Neumann series expansion [54]
$\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1}=\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(\boldsymbol{\Gamma} \mathbf{S})^{n}\right) \boldsymbol{\Gamma}=\boldsymbol{\Gamma}+\boldsymbol{\Gamma} \mathbf{S} \boldsymbol{\Gamma}+\boldsymbol{\Gamma} \mathbf{S} \boldsymbol{\Gamma} \mathbf{S} \boldsymbol{\Gamma}+\cdots$.
This series expansion has been widely utilized in the analysis of the mutual coupling in array signal processing [28], [46], [47]. Note that this expansion holds only when all the eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{\Gamma} \mathbf{S}$ are within the unit circle, i.e., $\left|\lambda_{i}(\boldsymbol{\Gamma} \mathbf{S})\right|<1$, $\forall i=1, \ldots, N_{\mathrm{f}}$. Fortunately, such a condition can be satisfied and the expression is valid for a typical MC strength.

Remark 4: When only the first term is considered, (35) reduces to the conventional model without RIS MC.

By retaining the first two terms of (35), $\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}^{-1}-\mathbf{S}\right)^{-1} \approx$ $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}+\boldsymbol{\Gamma} \mathbf{S} \boldsymbol{\Gamma}$, and we can rewrite (34) as

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\min _{\gamma} & -\left|\mathbf{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\gamma)+\operatorname{diag}(\gamma) \mathbf{S} \operatorname{diag}(\gamma)\right)\right|^{2} \\
\text { s.t. } & \|\gamma\|_{2}^{2} \leq A
\end{array}
$$

Notice the following relationship:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\gamma)\right) & =\left(\operatorname{diag}^{-1}\left(\operatorname{vec}^{-1}(\mathbf{t})\right)\right)^{\mathrm{T}} \gamma \\
\mathbf{t}^{\mathrm{T}} \operatorname{vec}\left(\operatorname{diag}(\gamma) \mathbf{S} \operatorname{diag}(\gamma)\right) & =\gamma^{\mathrm{T}}\left(\mathbf{S} \odot \operatorname{vec}^{-1}(\mathbf{t})\right) \gamma
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\operatorname{vec}^{-1}(\cdot)$ represents the operation of reshaping an $N^{2} \times$ 1 vector into an $N \times N$ square matrix while preserving the column-wise order, and $\operatorname{diag}^{-1}(\cdot)$ refers to the extraction of the diagonal entries of an $N \times N$ square matrix to form a $N \times 1$ column vector. Defining $\mathbf{q} \triangleq \operatorname{diag}^{-1}\left(\operatorname{vec}^{-1}\left(\mathbf{t}^{*}\right)\right), \mathbf{B} \triangleq$ $\mathbf{S} \odot \mathrm{vec}^{-1}(\mathbf{t})$, we can rewrite (36) as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\min _{\gamma} & -\left(\mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma+\gamma^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma\right)^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma+\gamma^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma\right) \\
\text { s.t. } & \|\gamma\|_{2}^{2} \leq A
\end{aligned}
$$

Although simplified, problem (39) is still challenging due to its non-convexity. In Section VI, we will adopt the SCA framework to solve this problem.

## VI. RIS CONFIGURATION OPTIMIZATION VIA SCA

This section presents an iterative solution to the non-convex optimization problem (39) by utilizing the SCA framework. A brief review of the SCA fundamentals is offered at Appendix B.

## A. Successive Convex Approximation of (39)

Based on the SCA principle presented in Appendix B, the following Proposition 1 proposes a surrogate function for the objective function in (39).

Proposition 1: For objective function $f(\gamma)=-\left(\mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma+\right.$ $\left.\gamma^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma\right)^{\mathrm{H}}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma+\gamma^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma\right)$ in (39), given an arbitrary feasible point $\gamma_{i}$, an associated surrogate function that satisfies Condition 1 and Condition 2 in Appendix B is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& g\left(\gamma \mid \gamma_{i}\right)=-\gamma^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{q} \mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma-\gamma^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{q} \gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma-\gamma^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}^{*} \mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma \\
& -\gamma^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}^{*} \gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma+K\left\|\gamma-\gamma_{i}\right\|_{2}^{2}-\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{q} \gamma^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma_{i} \\
& -\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma^{*} \mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}-\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma^{*} \gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma_{i}-\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}^{*} \gamma^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B} \gamma_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $K \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$is a parameter that must be chosen to ensure

$$
K \geq \lambda_{\max }\left(\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)
$$

where

$$
\mathbf{Q}_{i}=\mathbf{q} \mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}}+\mathbf{q} \gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B}+\mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}^{*} \mathbf{q}^{\mathrm{H}}+\mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}^{*} \gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \mathbf{B}
$$

Because $\mathbf{Q}_{i}$ is a Hermitian matrix, all its eigenvalues are real, resulting in a real $K$ in (41).
Proof: See Appendix C.

## B. Solving the Surrogate Optimization Problem

For the second step of SCA, we now consider optimizing the surrogate function $g\left(\gamma \mid \gamma_{i}\right)$. Based on (40), this surrogate optimization problem can be formulated as

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\min _{\gamma} & \gamma^{\mathrm{H}}\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right) \gamma-\mathbf{b}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \gamma-\mathbf{b}_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma^{*} \\
\text { s.t. } & \|\gamma\|_{2}^{2} \leq A
\end{array}
$$

where $\mathbf{b}_{i}=K \gamma_{i}^{*}+\left(\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{q}+\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}^{*}\right) \mathbf{B} \gamma_{i}$. Note that we omit the constant term in the objective function of (43).

Since the objective function $g\left(\gamma \mid \gamma_{i}\right)$ and the inequality constraint $\|\gamma\|_{2}^{2}-A$ in (43) are convex, and there exists strictly feasible points satisfying $\|\gamma\|_{2}^{2}<A$ (i.e., the Slater's condition is satisfied [55, Sec. 5.2.3]), the strong duality holds for (43). Therefore, the optimal solution of (43) can be found based on the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions.

To begin with, the Lagrangian associated with the problem (43) is derived as

$$
L(\gamma, \nu)=\gamma^{\mathrm{H}}\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right) \gamma-\mathbf{b}_{i}^{\mathrm{T}} \gamma-\mathbf{b}_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma^{*}+\nu\left(\gamma^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma-A\right)
$$

where $\nu \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ is the Lagrange multiplier (or dual variable) associated with the inequality constraint. Then, the KKT conditions indicate that the optimal primal and dual points, denoted as $\left(\gamma_{o}, \nu_{o}\right)$, must satisfy the following conditions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla_{\gamma} L\left(\gamma_{o}, \nu_{o}\right) & =\mathbf{0} \\
\nu_{\mathrm{o}}\left(\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{\mathrm{o}}-A\right) & =0 \\
\nu_{\mathrm{o}} & \geq 0 \\
\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{\mathrm{o}}-A & \leq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Based on (45a), we have

$$
\frac{\partial L\left(\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}, \nu_{\mathrm{o}}\right)}{\partial \gamma_{\mathrm{o}}^{*}}=\left(\frac{\partial L\left(\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}, \nu_{\mathrm{o}}\right)}{\partial \gamma_{\mathrm{o}}}\right)^{*}=\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right) \gamma_{\mathrm{o}}-\mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}+\nu_{\mathrm{o}} \gamma_{\mathrm{o}}=\mathbf{0}
$$

Algorithm 2 Expansion-and-Shrink Search Solution to (43)

```
Input: \(\mathbf{Q}_{i}, \mathbf{b}_{i}, A, K \quad\) Output: \(\gamma_{o}\).
if \(\left|\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\right|^{2} \leq A\) then
    \(\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}=\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\).
else
    Initialize \(\ell=1, u=\ell+1, \varsigma=1 \times 10^{-3}\).
    Set expansion-and-shrink rate \(\varepsilon_{\ell} \in(0,1)\) and \(\varepsilon_{u}>1\).
        while \(u-\ell>\varsigma\) do
            Compute \(P_{\ell}=\left|\left((K+\ell) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\right|^{2}\).
            Compute \(P_{u}=\left|\left((K+u) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\right|^{2}\).
            if \(P_{\ell}<A\) and \(P_{u}<A\) then
                \(u=\ell, \ell=\varepsilon_{\ell} \ell\).
            else if \(P_{\ell}>A\) and \(P_{u}>A\) then
                \(\ell=u, u=\varepsilon_{u} u\).
            else
                Compute \(P_{m}=\left|\left(\left(K+\frac{\ell+u}{2}\right) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\right|^{2}\).
                if \(P_{m} \leq A\) then
                    \(u=(\ell+u) / 2\).
            else
                \(\ell=(\ell+u) / 2\).
            \(\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}=\left(\left(K+\frac{\ell+u}{2}\right) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\).
```

This immediately yields $\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}=\left(\left(K+\nu_{\mathrm{o}}\right) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}$. The conditions in (41) and (45c) guarantee that all eigenvalues of $\left(\left(K+\nu_{\mathrm{o}}\right) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)$ lie in $\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$; thus, this matrix is always invertible. Subsequently, the value of the optimal primal solution $\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}$ can be inferred in the following two cases:

1) $\nu_{\mathrm{o}}=0$ : In this case, the optimal primal solution is

$$
\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}= \begin{cases}\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}, & \text { if }\left|\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\right|^{2} \leq A \\ \text { does not exist, } & \text { otherwise. }\end{cases}
$$

2) $\nu_{\mathrm{o}}>0$ : In this case, the optimal primal solution $\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}$ must satisfy

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}=\left(\left(K+\nu_{\mathrm{o}}\right) \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*} \\
\left|\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}\right|^{2}=A
\end{array}\right.
$$

By observing (47), we see that $\left|\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}\right|^{2}$ is monotonically decreasing w.r.t $\nu_{\mathrm{o}}$. Therefore, we can infer

$$
\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}= \begin{cases}\text { does not exist, } & \text { if }\left|\left(K \mathbf{I}-\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)^{-1} \mathbf{b}_{i}^{*}\right|^{2} \leq A \\ \text { solution of (47) and (48), } & \text { otherwise. }\end{cases}
$$

Here, equations (47) and (48) can be solved by performing an expansion-and-shrink search on $\nu_{\mathrm{o}}$. Algorithm 2 summarizes the steps of solving the surrogate problem (43).

## C. Solving (39) Using SCA

Based on the convex approximation in Section VI-A and the corresponding solution in Section VI-B, we summarize the complete SCA procedure for solving (39) in Algorithm 3, which follows the SCA principle in Appendix B. As mentioned, the step size $\eta_{i}$ of the iteration can be chosen according to different rules. As an example, here we present a line search rule [56] for determining $\eta_{i}$. Again, let $f(\gamma)$ denote the objective function in (39) and choose $\delta_{1}, \delta_{2} \in(0,1)$. The

Algorithm 3 Solving (39) Using SCA

```
Input: q, B, A. Output: \(\gamma_{*}\).
    Initialize \(i=0\) and randomly select \(\gamma_{0},\left\|\gamma_{0}\right\|^{2} \leq A\).
for \(i \in \mathbb{N}\) do
        Compute \(\mathbf{Q}_{i}\) using (42) and select \(K \geq \lambda_{\max }\left(\mathbf{Q}_{i}\right)\).
        Compute \(\mathbf{b}_{i}=K \gamma_{i}^{*}+\left(\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{q}+\gamma_{i}^{\mathrm{H}} \mathbf{B}^{\mathrm{H}} \gamma_{i}^{*}\right) \mathbf{B} \gamma_{i}\).
        Apply Algorithm 2 to solve (43) and obtain \(\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}\).
        Let \(\tilde{\gamma}_{i+1}=\gamma_{\mathrm{o}}\) and choose a step size \(\eta_{i}\) through (49).
        Update \(\gamma_{i+1}=\gamma_{i}+\eta_{i}\left(\tilde{\gamma}_{i+1}-\gamma_{i}\right)\).
        Stop if \(\left\|\gamma_{i+1}-\gamma_{i}\right\|_{2}\) is lower than a preset threshold.
    return \(\gamma_{*}=\gamma_{i+1}\).
```

line search rule chooses $\eta_{i}=\delta_{1}^{n_{i}}$, where $n_{i}$ is the smallest natural number satisfying

$$
f\left(\gamma_{i}+\eta_{i} \Delta \gamma_{i}\right) \leq f\left(\gamma_{i}\right)+\delta_{2} \eta_{i}\left(\left(\nabla_{\gamma^{*}} f\left(\gamma_{i}\right)\right)^{\mathrm{H}} \Delta \gamma_{i}\right)
$$

where $\Delta \gamma_{i} \triangleq \tilde{\gamma}_{i+1}-\gamma_{i}$ and $\tilde{\gamma}_{i+1}$ denotes the solution of (43). Here, $\nabla_{\gamma^{*}} f\left(\gamma_{i}\right)=\partial f\left(\gamma_{i}\right) / \partial \gamma^{*}$, which is the direction where $f$ increases fastest at $\gamma_{i}$ [57, Theorem 3.4].

## VII. SIMULATION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
## A. Simulation Setup

Throughout the simulations, we position the UE at $2.6 \mathrm{~m} \times$ $\left[\sin \frac{\pi}{6}, \cos \frac{\pi}{6}, 0\right]^{\mathrm{T}}$, the RIS at $[0,0,0]^{\mathrm{T}}$ facing the positive Y-axis, and the BS at $2.2 \mathrm{~m} \times\left[\sin \frac{\pi}{2}, \cos \frac{\pi}{2}, 0\right]^{\mathrm{T}}$ facing the negative Y-axis, consistent with the far-field measurement setup in [49]. We set the signal frequency $f_{c}=30 \mathrm{GHz}$ and the thermal noise power $\sigma_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}=\sigma_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}=-95 \mathrm{dBm}$, according to [49, Fig. 25]. The RIS is composed of $N_{\mathrm{I}}=16 \times 8$ elements with $d_{\mathrm{I}}=\lambda / 20$ while the BS and UE deployy $N_{\mathrm{B}}=4 \times 2$ and $N_{\mathrm{U}}=2 \times 1$ elements with $d_{\mathrm{B}}=d_{\mathrm{U}}=\lambda / 2$. Regarding the channel generation, we use $L_{\mathrm{U}}=2$, the LoS path gain in (1) is $\alpha_{1}=\left(\lambda /\left(4 \pi d_{\mathrm{IU}}\right)\right)^{\gamma_{\mathrm{IU}} / 2}$, where $d_{\mathrm{IU}}$ is the distance between the UE and RIS, and the path loss exponent $\gamma_{\mathrm{IU}}=2.1$. For NLoS paths $\alpha_{\ell} \sim \mathcal{C N}\left(0, \alpha_{\ell}^{2}\right)$. The same logic applies to $\rho_{\ell}$ in (4) with $L_{\mathrm{B}}=2$.

The scattering matrix $\mathbf{S}$ is obtained by first calculating the mutual impedances ( $\mathbf{Z}$ matrix) based on the analytical model in [18, Eq.(2)]. Then, it is converted to scattering parameters ( $\mathbf{S}$ matrix) by applying $\mathbf{S}=\left(\mathbf{Z}+Z_{0} \mathbf{I}\right)^{-1}\left(\mathbf{Z}-Z_{0} \mathbf{I}\right)$ [26, Eq.(24)], where $Z_{0}=50 \Omega$ is the characteristic impedance. Here, $\mathbf{S}$ is a function of RIS inter-element spacing, with denser element integration typically resulting in stronger mutual coupling [18, Fig. 2]. Unless stated otherwise, we set $A=896$, i.e., the RIS has an average amplification factor $\bar{a}=\sqrt{A / N_{\mathrm{I}}}=7$. The training uses random phase shifts, uniformly distributed as $\mathcal{U}(0,2 \pi)$. We perform 100 trials to average each simulation point in the results (e.g. transmit power, RIS inter-element spacing, etc.), where at each trial different random beamformer, combiner, and RIS configurations are used, following the training procedure in Section III-A. We set $M_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{3 N_{\mathrm{I}}}{4}$ $M_{\mathrm{I}}=\frac{3 N_{\mathrm{I}}}{4}, \dot{L}=5, G_{\mathrm{I}}=N_{\mathrm{I}}$, and $G_{\mathrm{B}}=N_{\mathrm{B}}$.

It is important to clarify that our simulations consider arbitrary AoA and AoD , as this provides a more practical and realistic scenario. Consequently, we anticipate a reduction in estimation accuracy due to the off-grid power leakage effect

associated with the used on-grid OMP. However, this performance loss can be mitigated by selecting larger dictionaries (e.g., $G_{\mathrm{I}}=2 N_{\mathrm{I}}, G_{\mathrm{B}}=2 N_{\mathrm{B}}$ ) or by leveraging more advanced off-grid estimation methods.

## B. Performance Metrics

Based on Section III and Section IV, we can estimate the conventional and exact equivalent cascaded channel $\overline{\mathbf{G}}_{\mathrm{cv}} \in$ $\mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} \times N_{\mathrm{I}}}$ and $\overline{\mathbf{G}}_{\mathrm{mc}} \in \mathbb{C}^{N_{\mathrm{B}} \times N_{\mathrm{I}}^{2}}$ based on the conventional MCunaware model and the exact MC-awre model, respectively. Since $\overline{\mathbf{G}}_{\mathrm{cv}}$ and $\overline{\mathbf{G}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ have different dimensions, for a fair comparison, we evaluate the estimation accuracy by computing the normalized mean squared error (NMSE) of the reconstructed received signal as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{NMSE}_{\mathrm{cv}}=\mathbb{E}\left\|\overline{\mathbf{P}} \overline{\mathbf{G}}_{\mathrm{cv}} \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{cv}}-\overline{\mathbf{Y}}\right\|_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} /\|\overline{\mathbf{Y}}\|_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} \\
& \mathrm{NMSE}_{\mathrm{mc}}=\mathbb{E}\left\|\overline{\mathbf{P}} \overline{\mathbf{G}}_{\mathrm{mc}} \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{\mathrm{mc}}-\overline{\mathbf{Y}}\right\|_{\mathrm{F}}^{2} /\|\overline{\mathbf{Y}}\|_{\mathrm{F}}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\overline{\mathbf{Y}}$ is the noise-free version of the received signal.
The computational complexity of Algorithm 1 is dominated by OMP's complexity that mainly depends on the used sensing matrix $\boldsymbol{\Xi}$ size, $\mathcal{C}_{\mathrm{OMP}}=\mathcal{O}\left(\bar{L} M_{\mathrm{I}} M_{\mathrm{B}} J(\boldsymbol{\Xi})\right)$ [37]. Here, $J(\boldsymbol{\Xi})$ denotes the number of columns of the used $\boldsymbol{\Xi}$. Hence, we define the effective size metric $\zeta_{\nu}=J\left(\boldsymbol{\Xi}_{\nu}\right) / J\left(\boldsymbol{\Xi}_{\mathrm{mc}}\right), \nu \in$ $\{\mathrm{cv}, \mathrm{DR}\}$ as the ratio of sensing matrix columns for the adopted method to the exact model sensing matrix columns.

For the beamforming performance, we evaluate the spectral efficiency of given $\{\mathbf{f}, \mathbf{w}, \boldsymbol{\gamma}\}$ as $\mathrm{SE}=\log _{2}(1+\mathrm{SNR})$ using the accurate definition of SNR in (29).

## C. Channel Estimation Performance Evaluation

Fig. 4(a) presents the channel estimation NMSE versus transmit power in the uplink. As demonstrated, the proposed two-stage algorithm consistently outperforms the conventional MC-unaware OMP in the presence of MC. Even for small values of DR factor $\rho_{\mathrm{DR}}$, our method achieves several dB

For $\rho_{\mathrm{DR}} \geq 0.1$, the proposed algorithm performs on par with the direct MC-aware OMP (without dictionary reduction). However, as depicted in Fig. 4(b), lower $\rho_{\mathrm{DR}}$ results in reduced complexity, highlighting a trade-off between performance and complexity. Notably, when $\rho_{\mathrm{DR}}=0.1$, our DR method reduces the dictionary size to $5.04 \%$ of that in the direct MC-aware OMP, adding only about $10 \%$ additional complexity compared to the conventional MC-unaware method. Despite this low cost, this two-stage solution (conv. estimation $\left(\zeta_{\nu}=50.39 \%\right)+$ DR estimation $\left(\zeta_{\nu}=5.04 \%\right)$ ) achieves performance comparable to the accurate direct MCaware OMP ( $\zeta_{\nu}=100 \%$ ), demonstrating the superiority of the proposed approach.

Fig. 5 examines the effect of the RIS amplification factor on channel estimation accuracy. We observe that under a low amplification factor ( $\bar{a} \leq 2.5$ ), the conventional and proposed methods perform similarly, and both with accuracy improving as the RIS amplification increases, indicating a negligible impact of MC. However, as the RIS amplification factor continues to increase, the performance of the conventional MCunaware OMP deteriorates and diverges from the proposed

This suggests that simply increasing RIS power is not always beneficial unless MC is well managed. In contrast, our proposed method effectively accounts for the MC mechanism, allowing it to consistently benefit from increased RIS amplification, even with a low dictionary reduction factor, such as $\rho_{\mathrm{DR}}=0.1$.

In Fig. 6, the effect of different MC levels is investigated by varying the RIS inter-element spacing. When the RIS spacing is large $\left(d_{\mathrm{I}}>\lambda / 10\right)$, the MC effect is weak, and thus the performance of the MC-unaware OMP and the proposed method with appropriate dictionary reduction factors ( $\rho_{\mathrm{DR}} \geq 1$ or no reduction) is similar. Nevertheless, with shorter RIS spacing $\left(d_{\mathrm{I}}<\lambda / 10\right)$, the MC-unaware OMP suffers significant performance degradation, which is exacerbated as the MC effect intensifies. The proposed method, however, maintains a performance gain of over 20 dB under strong-MC conditions.

Fig. 7 depicts the beamforming optimization objective value in (31) over the iteration of our proposed SCA and the existing GD algorithm, ${ }^{8}$ given the ground truth cascaded channel $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{me}}$. The proposed SCA secures two gains compared to GD: (i) higher beamforming gain, and (ii) higher efficiency (less number of iterations). For example, with 20 iterations, SCA achieves more than triple the gain compared to GD.

Now, we focus on the beamforming gains of the proposed strategy and at the same time, incorporate the estimated channel. Hence, we present both scenarios; the first assumes perfect CSI, and the second utilizes the output of the proposed channel estimation algorithm (i.e., partial CSI). This is different from the majority of the existing literature, where authors try to simulate partial CSI by simply adding some random variables (typically following normal or uniform distributions) to the ground truth channel to change either channel gains (most common) or the AoA/AoD.

Since we use regular dictionaries (i.e., with no oversampling) for the OMP and choose arbitrary AoA and AoD, we select $L_{\mathrm{U}}=L_{\mathrm{B}}=1$ to minimize the power leakage effect of OMP. We set $d_{\mathrm{I}}=\lambda / 10, \bar{a}=7, P_{\mathrm{U}}=5 \mathrm{~mW}, P_{\mathrm{B}}=10 \mathrm{~mW}$. Fig. 8 evaluates the spectral efficiency of different channel estimation and beamforming methods by changing the BS transmit power $P_{\mathrm{B}}$ in the downlink. In addition to the MCaware beamforming approaches based on $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ (using either SCA or GD), we also assess the conventional MC-unaware beamforming based on $\mathbf{G}_{\mathrm{cv}}$, which is addressed using SVD [58]. It is evident that the proposed SCA-based MC-aware solution achieves the highest spectral efficiency in both perfect and partial CSI cases. Moreover, the spectral efficiency achieved with the estimated $\hat{\mathbf{G}}_{\mathrm{mc}}$ from the proposed channel estimation method is only slightly lower than that with the ground truth channel, which again confirms the effectiveness of the proposed channel estimator. A similar trend is observed with the GD-based MC-aware beamforming method.

Analogous to Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 assess the spectral efficiency with varying RIS amplification factors and inter-element spacings, respectively. Both figures demonstrate that the proposed SCA-based MC-aware method consistently achieves the highest spectral efficiency. An interesting observation is that, as the impact of MC increases, the performance gain of the proposed SCA-based solution initially improves but eventually declines. This occurs because the Neumann series approximation (35) becomes less accurate when MC is excessively strong. In addition, in Fig. 10, we note a significant high spectral efficiency between $d_{\mathrm{I}}=\lambda / 16$ and $d_{\mathrm{I}}=\lambda / 8$. Since this setup does not increase RIS power but only shifts the inter-element spacing, it suggests that with sophisticated signal processing solutions, additional gains can be obtained from MC. This observation indicates that the prevailing view of MC as solely a negative effect may be biased.

## VIII. CONCLUSION

This paper addresses the challenges of channel estimation and beamforming in active RIS-assisted MIMO communication systems in the presence of MC. Our findings demonstrate that conventional MC-unaware channel estimators underperform in scenarios with strong MC, highlighting the need for accurate modeling and novel algorithms. By employing the CS and DR techniques, we propose a low-complexity yet accurate channel estimator that performs effectively under strong MC conditions. Moreover, we reveal that even with accurate channel estimation, an effective MC-aware beamforming approach is essential for achieving decent spectral efficiency. To this end, we propose an alternating beamforming algorithm based on Neumann series expansion and the SCA optimization framework. Numerical results confirm the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed algorithms, benchmarked against state-of-the-art approaches. Overall, this work underscores the critical importance of MC-awareness in RIS-assisted channel estimation and beamforming, particularly in RIS configurations with high amplification and small inter-element spacing.

## APPENDIX B
## BACKGROUND OF SUCCESSIVE CONVEX APPROXIMATION

SCA is a general framework that can decompose a complex optimization problem into a series of simpler optimization problems [56], [59]. Consider the following general optimization problem as an example:

$$
\min _{\mathbf{x}} f(\mathbf{x}), \quad \text { s.t. } \mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{X}
$$

The SCA framework generates a sequence of descending feasible points $\left\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}}$ through a cyclic application of two steps: (i) formulating a simpler surrogate function (which is convex) at the current feasible point, and (ii) optimizing the surrogate function to acquire an improved feasible point.

1) Formulating Surrogate Functions: At each feaible point $\mathbf{x}_{i}$, the SCA method formulates a surrogate function $g\left(\mathbf{x} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$ satisfying the following two conditions:

Condition 1: $g\left(\mathbf{x} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$ is convex on $\mathcal{X}, \forall \mathbf{x}_{i} \in \mathcal{X}$.
Condition 2: $g\left(\mathbf{x} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$ is differentiable on $\mathcal{X}$ and its gradient equals to the gradient of $f(\mathbf{x})$ at $\mathbf{x}_{i}$, i.e., $\nabla g\left(\mathbf{x} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)_{\mid \mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{i}}=$ $\nabla f(\mathbf{x})_{\mid \mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{i}}$.

2) Optimizing Surrogate Functions: Once a surrogate function $g\left(\mathbf{x} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$ that satisfies Condition 1 and Condition 2 is obtained, we can obtain a descending direction of $f(\mathbf{x})$ by addressing the following convex optimization problem:

$$
\dot{\mathbf{x}}_{i+1}=\arg \min _{\mathbf{x}} g\left(\mathbf{x} \mid \mathbf{x}_{i}\right), \quad \text { s.t. } \mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{X}
$$

Then, we update the feasible point as $\mathbf{x}_{i+1}=\mathbf{x}_{i}+\eta_{i}\left(\dot{\mathbf{x}}_{i+1}-\right.$ $\left.\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)$, where $\eta_{i} \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$is the step size. Various rules for selecting the step size are outlined in [56, Assumption 3.6], and the convergence of this iterative SCA procedure has been established by [56, Theorem 3.7].

abstract:
This work studies the problems of channel estimation and beamforming for
active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted multiple-input
multiple-output (MIMO) communication, incorporating the mutual coupling (MC)
effect through an electromagnetically consistent model based on scattering
parameters. We first demonstrate that MC can be incorporated into a compressed
sensing (CS) estimation formulation, albeit with an increase in the
dimensionality of the sensing matrix. To overcome this increased complexity, we
propose a two-stage strategy. Initially, a low-complexity MC-unaware CS
estimation is performed to obtain a coarse channel estimate, which is then used
to implement a dictionary reduction (DR), effectively reducing the
dimensionality of the sensing matrices. This method achieves low complexity
comparable to the conventional MC-unaware approach while providing estimation
accuracy close to that of the high-complexity MC-aware CS method. Furthermore,
we consider the joint optimization of RIS configuration, base station
precoding, and user combining in an single-user MIMO system. We employ an
alternating optimization strategy to optimize these three beamformers. The
primary challenge lies in optimizing the RIS configuration, as the MC effect
renders the problem non-convex and intractable. To address this, we propose a
novel algorithm based on the successive convex approximation (SCA) and the
Neumann series expansion. Within the SCA framework, we propose a surrogate
function that rigorously satisfies both convexity and equal-gradient conditions
to update the iteration direction. Numerical results validate our proposal,
demonstrating that the proposed channel estimation and beamforming methods
effectively manage the MC in RIS, achieving higher spectral efficiency compared
to state-of-the-art approaches.
